repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Rural Poverty Alleviation Project Maranhao

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Rural Poverty
            Alleviation Project Maranhao for Brazil  was satisfactory,
            the sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned were
            that: 1) decentralization of fiscal and investment
            decision-making and implementation at the state and local
            levels, results in administrative efficiency and superior
            results; 2) by assigning responsibility to local communities
            and their organizations, and by involving the municipal
            government as a partner, community-driven development (CDD)
            approaches can successfully support decentralized resource
            allocation and create social capital in even the poorest
            rural areas; 3) self-selection of beneficiaries results in
            strong targeting; 4) alignment of community investments with
            the Municipal Human Development Index (HDI-M) as a targeting
            and mobilizing goal, is both a logical evolution of the
            Northeast CDD approach and an important way to further scale
            it up; 5) natural resources management (NRM) and
            sustainability issues require proactive attention in
            environmentally fragile states; 6) productive subprojects
            are likely to assume greater prominence under the new
            project; 7) municipal councils can play a broader role in
            local planning; 8) indigenous community organizations can
            establish and express priorities, and administer resources
            received; 9) intensive supervision which includes the use of
            local entities closest to the communities, is an
            indispensable determinant of success and sustainability for
            CDD projects; 10) technical assistance is an essential
            ingredient for CDD projects and presents particular
            challenges for its systematic organization, location,
            delivery and supervision in poor rural regions; 11) the
            project management information system (MIS) is capable of
            generating real-time data/reports on the full subproject
            cycle and supporting monitoring and evaluation activities;
            12) standardized subproject documents, technical designs and
            unit costs simplify sub-project preparation and evaluation,
            improve sub-project quality, facilitate procurement, prevent
            over- and under-design, and promote the participation of
            poorer communities; and 13) checks and balances are
            essential to ensure proper targeting and use of resources
            and to boost and institutionalize transparency.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Northeast Rural Poverty
            Alleviation Program Project - Maranhao

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Poverty Alleviation Project,
            based on the Northeast Rural Poverty Alleviation Program,
            assists the state government of Maranhao in alleviating
            rural poverty by a) providing basic social and economic
            infrastructure, and employment and income-generating
            opportunities; b) decentralizing resource allocation and
            decisionmaking; c) leveraging resources mobilized at the
            community level; and d) deepening the creation of social
            capital. The project has three components: 1) community
            subprojects, which support small-scale investments selected
            and subsequently operated and maintained by beneficiaries;
            2) institutional development, which provides all
            implementing entities and communities with technical
            assistance and training to increase capacity and improve
            project implementation; and 3) project administration,
            supervision, monitoring, and evaluation, which finances
            project coordination and activities to provide feedback on
            project performance and impact.
